rounds.comments: (Alex: A person, place, or thing, you tell us.)

clues.text:
A "Solo" actor,
a good spot to cross a river,
a car company

An L.A. Laker,
a city in Japan,
a type of beef

A "Fresh Prince",
a Kansas county,
a women's college

A modern rock piano-playing chanteuse,
a "Valley" north of San Bernardino,
a fruit

A "Big Bang Theory" actor,
a city in Kansas,
a "New School for Design"
This Austen title character "had lived nearly 21 years in the world with very little to distress or vex her"
The first entry of her diary is "129 lbs. (but post-Christmas), alcohol units 14... cigarettes 22, calories 5424"
"The Curious Incident Of The Dog In The Night-time", he points out to a police inspector, is that the dog did nothing
She plans to draw a picture of herself & write under it, "Portrait of a governess, disconnected, poor, and plain"
"Once upon a time there were four little rabbits, and their names were--Flopsy, Mopsy, Cotton-tail, & Peter", she wrote

George Bailey (Jimmy Stewart):
The town of Bedford Falls in this Christmas film

James Bailey:
The circus, merging with this impresario's "Greatest Show On Earth" in 1881
Kay Bailey Hutchison: being the first woman to represent this state in the U.S. Senate
This man, first name Francis, the courtroom, as when representing Dr. Sam Sheppard & Patty Hearst

David Bailey, the inspiration for Antonioni's "Blow-up":
this field for British Vogue
Nicholas II
Queen Wilhelmina

An empire:
Sultan Abdulhamid II
Porfiro Diaz
Wilhelm II, German Kaiser & king of this former state
The numerical record of a sporting event, it comes from the Old Norse for 20 & also means 20
This ballroom dance gets its name from the Spanish for "revelry", not from a liquor
Derived from the Latin for "high", it's an adjective meaning proud & scornful
From the Greek for "pleasure", it's the term for an unbridled pursuit of it
The name of this sudden, overwhelming terror or fear comes from the Greek god thought to cause it
Plato was a teacher of this Greek philosopher & scientist who also became a colleague
The followers of this philosopher & mathematician are the foils in "Phaedo"; they don't take the right angle
Plato's unfinished "Critias" was to detail the ancient war between Athens & this fabled island
In 529 A.D. almost 1,000 years after it was created by Plato, this school was closed by Justinian I
This work is about an ideal city where justice is complete & imitative poets are exiled
In May 2012 this band of superheroes had the biggest box-office weekend of all time with $207 mil. domestically
Anne Hathaway is feline groovy as "cat" burglar Selina Kyle in this 2012 film
In 2012 Nicolas Cage reprised this title role as Johnny Blaze, a motorcyclist who gives up his soul to become a vigilante
Gerard Christopher played the young hero in this 1988-1992 TV series; Stacy Haiduk was Lana Lang
This team first came to TV in 1967 as an animated series on which Jo Ann Pflug voiced the Invisible Woman
At 1,538 miles, it has the longest border with Canada of any U.S. state
This state's Erie county has a 42-mile border with Canada; don't try to drive across it
All of Washington's 427-mile border with Canada is with this province
Presque Isle in this eastern state is less than 10 miles from our neighbors
The geographic center of North America is in this state bordering Saskatchewan & Manitoba
For designing the tallest of his era, like the Woolworth building, Cass Gilbert was "the father of" this type of structure
W.C. Handy was "the father of" this musical style
In 2012 "the father of the Internet", Vint Cerf, said the U.S. government really started it via this department
It's all according to this man who was "the father of whist" for systematizing the card game
"The Father of History", this ancient Greek wrote a 9-volume work on the wars between Greece & Persia
Fireplace residue
It's what covers a mink
To tidy "up" or neaten
To yearn for the one you love
The person who plants the fruit pips so they'll grow
Its prologue begins, "Whan that Aprill with his shoures soote/ The droghte of March hath perced to the roote"
Her poem No. 1333 begins, "a little madness in the spring/ is wholesome even for the king"
It's the title of Rachel Carson's landmark 1962 work warning of the dangers of pesticide use
"It was the spring of hope, it was the winter of despair" is from the famous opening line of this novel
Huck Finn said "when you've got" this, "you don't quite know what it is you do want, but it just fairly makes your heart ache"
Galatea, one of its moons, is named for the daughter of a sea god
Saturn has a moon named this, also the name of a moon in "Avatar"
Some astronomers believe that these 2 moons of Mars were asteroids at one time
Uranus' 2 largest moons are Titania & this one, named for a fairy king
This 2-letter moon of Jupiter is the most volcanically active body in the solar system

rounds.text: Once its own city, it joined with a neighbor in 1898; today on its own it would be the 4th most populous city in the U.S.
